What He Really Said
But what Mr. Kemler really said about headlines we
reveal below:
Headlines, he says, are to the journalist what ceremony is to the priest. To appreciate this, you must know
first of all what a journalist is. In essence, a,journalist is
one who writes but does not communicate — either
through ignorance or fear. He is a gossip who would be
completely shut up if the world were not sinful. He
thrives on murder, war, and repine. And yet, in himself, the journalist can communicate nothing—no imagination, thought, or beauty. For should a journalist
really utter something worthwhile, he is no longer true
to his profession.
From all appearances then, that profession is very
low. Very wretched, indeed. The fact of the matter is
that these reprobates, not so very king ago, realized that
something would have to be done. So members of the
profession got together on a most auspicious and hypothetical occasion—and devised a set of rules for their
trade, very complicated and mysterious. It was a code
of headline writing of such a forbidding nature that it
can only be likened to the Sibyllene Books of Rome.
And the journalists, naturally, were its High Priests!—
the sole interpreters! •
Why did they do it? That is very obvious. That
terrible code immediately raised journalism from the
position of a down-trodden art to an unfathomable cult,
worthy of highest reverence. Headlines, today, are the
raison d'etre of whatever dignity journalists—and colcollege journalists—have. The rules for type, drops,
streamers, and titles are as inflexible as the physical
laws of motion. Our colleagues watch over our front
page like a band of hungry hawks. For the Sacred Caption is a jealous caption—and must have its
full share of worship.
How wide has the cult spread? In the collegiate
world, we can report that there are High Priests all
over the Eastern institutions. In fact, journalism has
achieved such a reputation by its shrew intricacies that
many colleges give courses therein. Indeed, at Columbia, there is a whole department given over to the super
stition—a sort of seminary for the headline-priesthood.
Our own Hopkins colleagues have devoted as much as
fifteen hours an issue merely in their devotion to its
principles. And if one little caption should be up-sidedown, letters will pour in for weeks with stormy denunciation from every college editor in the country. It's a
remarkable tradition.!
In this issue, we have burned the Sacred Books. We
shall be denounced far and wide. On all sides. For we
have burned the very life-blood of our fellow-journalists. They are watching a frightful auto-da-fe, in
which their dignity, their mysteries, their superstitious
lore are turning into smoke! For we have momentarily done away with all orthodox headlines. If we are
successful, then let college journalism look to its grave!
Some time ago, a local priest argued that headlinewriting builds character. We present this argument to
our readers ,for what it's worth. Character, indeed?
Let us not take such decadent apologies. We want
the truth. And let this issue be a monument--or an
E. K.
epitaph to Reason!

Remarks On Chemistry
It has been reported that professors at the Johns
Hopkins School of Medicine have remarked on the unpolished technique displayed by chemistry students from
the undergraduate school. This situation is no cause
for amazement when we consider the ignorance of many
of the students in regard to the most fundamental
dictates of technique.
We refer to the simple manipulation of pouring
liquids from a bottle into a receptacle. In this operation, the bottle is held with the label beneath the palm

In the Organic and Inorganic laboratory the students either don't know or don't care about this rule.
Consequently, many bottles, particularly those containing acid, are in a condition which makes it dangerous to handle them.
If this state of affairs is the result of oversight by
the instructors, we suggest that they rectify a situation

Letter To The Editor
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Sir, I am taking this occasion to relate my pleasure
upon reading a recent article, entitled "Minsky and
Benny."
I, myself, have made an especial study of the subject
contained therein—to-wit, the burlesque; and, sir, let
me say that. your correspondent has by no means exaggerated. Burlesque today is one of the most respectable and justly remunerative professions there is. Cantor, Wynn, J. E. Brown, and many others have used
it as a spring-board to fame. And since the ,vaudeville
business has been dealt a serious blow by the talkies,
there can be no doubt of it. The illegitimate theatre
has come into its own! Even I, sir, have contemplated
giving up my pulpit work to sport about like a carefree child over the happy boards.
I have often visited the local burlesque palaces, sir,
and I assure you that the prolific abundance of rare
women was amazing to me no less than to your correspondent I, too, was interested.
With best of wishes,
HUGO D. WEISGALL,
Graduate Student In History.

President Roosevelt unknowingly
arranged for the serenade in October,
1933, when he was gracefully extricating himself from the fiasco resulting from an undergraduate's prank.
An unknown campus wag wrote President Roosevelt asking if the bells
could be named for him. A warm acceptance was sent to Prof. J. L. Coolidge, the President saying he was

to honor President Roosevelt in this
way and to inform him that he had
been the victim of a prank.
Upon learning the truth, President
Roosevelt declared, "In spite of it all,
the next time I go to Cambridge, I
propose to listen to those bells." So
far, it has ben impossible to tune the
bells and to find an experienced Russian player. Consequently, his dinner music will probably consist of

Jay Natators The Truth
In Final Meet Will Out

By KEN ZIERLER

Dr. Shaffer said, "It's a good policy
to know the truth."

Hopkins Faces Delaware Fish
At K. Of C. Pool Tonight;
MacGill Expected To Star

Delaware Powerful
Additional Encounter May
Be Held With RandolphMacon College Tankers
In an attempt to score their third
win of the season, the Jay natators
will come to grips with the strong
Delaware aggregation in the K. of C.
pool tonight. The contest will mark
the end of dual meet competition for
the season, and Hopkins is anxious
to close up its campaign with a victory.
The job ahead of them is particularly difficult, however, because Delaware possesses one of the strongest
teams in the history of the college.
The opposing natators number among
their victims Carnegie Tech, a university that perennially turns out a
powerful squad and is one of the
strongest teams of the Eastern Intercollegiate League.
The Blue Jays will depend on the
same squad that took the trip to
Villanova and Manhattan last week to
garner points in the forthcoming engagement.
Coach
Hambleton's
charges experienced a rather successful week-end, trouncing Villanova
and tying the New Yorkers in
points, although losing the encounter
on a technical ruling.
Featuring the trip was the shattering of two records, the 150-yard
backstroke and the 200-yard breaststroke. Johnny MacGill accounted
for the former mark against Manhattan, covering the distance in 1:55
to cut 4-5 of a second off his own
record. Bill Hazlett lowered the
breaststroke time from Eddie Sadtler's performance of 2:50 to 2:47.
MacGill and Danny Weiner are
looked for to tally heavily in the
dorsal swim, while Hazlett and Bishop should bring the Jays some points
in the breaststroke. In the sprints
Lou Adler, who scored well against
Manhattan; Don Noonan and Charlie
Jones will compete against the dash
men from Delaware. Eddie Scheer and
Bud Adler will swim the 220 and 440,
the former having captured the
shorter race against Villanova. Bill
Koenig, winner against Manhattan,
and Capt. Bill McConnell will vie
with the opposition for the judge's
decision in the diving.
While the Delaware encounter is
the last meet on the regular schedule, there is a possibility of a contest
with Randolph-Macon if the Jays can
provide a satisfactory guarantee.
Some of the members of the team
also plan to travel to Pittsburgh for
the Eastern Collegiate championships, while it is planned to enter the
squad in the South Atlantics.

What He Really Said
But what Mr. Kemler really said about headlines we
reveal below:
Headlines, he says, are to the journalist what ceremony is to the priest. To appreciate this, you must know
first of all what a journalist is. In essence, a,journalist is
one who writes but does not communicate — either
through ignorance or fear. He is a gossip who would be
completely shut up if the world were not sinful. He
thrives on murder, war, and repine. And yet, in himself, the journalist can communicate nothing—no imagination, thought, or beauty. For should a journalist
really utter something worthwhile, he is no longer true
to his profession.
From all appearances then, that profession is very
low. Very wretched, indeed. The fact of the matter is
that these reprobates, not so very king ago, realized that
something would have to be done. So members of the
profession got together on a most auspicious and hypothetical occasion—and devised a set of rules for their
trade, very complicated and mysterious. It was a code
of headline writing of such a forbidding nature that it
can only be likened to the Sibyllene Books of Rome.
And the journalists, naturally, were its High Priests!—
the sole interpreters! •
Why did they do it? That is very obvious. That
terrible code immediately raised journalism from the
position of a down-trodden art to an unfathomable cult,
worthy of highest reverence. Headlines, today, are the
raison d'etre of whatever dignity journalists—and colcollege journalists—have. The rules for type, drops,
streamers, and titles are as inflexible as the physical
laws of motion. Our colleagues watch over our front
page like a band of hungry hawks. For the Sacred Caption is a jealous caption—and must have its
full share of worship.
How wide has the cult spread? In the collegiate
world, we can report that there are High Priests all
over the Eastern institutions. In fact, journalism has
achieved such a reputation by its shrew intricacies that
many colleges give courses therein. Indeed, at Columbia, there is a whole department given over to the super
stition—a sort of seminary for the headline-priesthood.
Our own Hopkins colleagues have devoted as much as
fifteen hours an issue merely in their devotion to its
principles. And if one little caption should be up-sidedown, letters will pour in for weeks with stormy denunciation from every college editor in the country. It's a
remarkable tradition.!
In this issue, we have burned the Sacred Books. We
shall be denounced far and wide. On all sides. For we
have burned the very life-blood of our fellow-journalists. They are watching a frightful auto-da-fe, in
which their dignity, their mysteries, their superstitious
lore are turning into smoke! For we have momentarily done away with all orthodox headlines. If we are
successful, then let college journalism look to its grave!
Some time ago, a local priest argued that headlinewriting builds character. We present this argument to
our readers ,for what it's worth. Character, indeed?
Let us not take such decadent apologies. We want
the truth. And let this issue be a monument--or an
E. K.
epitaph to Reason!

Remarks On Chemistry
It has been reported that professors at the Johns
Hopkins School of Medicine have remarked on the unpolished technique displayed by chemistry students from
the undergraduate school. This situation is no cause
for amazement when we consider the ignorance of many
of the students in regard to the most fundamental
dictates of technique.
We refer to the simple manipulation of pouring
liquids from a bottle into a receptacle. In this operation, the bottle is held with the label beneath the palm

In the Organic and Inorganic laboratory the students either don't know or don't care about this rule.
Consequently, many bottles, particularly those containing acid, are in a condition which makes it dangerous to handle them.
If this state of affairs is the result of oversight by
the instructors, we suggest that they rectify a situation
which reflects no credit to their ability as teachers.
On the other hand, if the students are at fault, we
should like to remind them that even Koch and Lister
had to learn how to pour liquids before they made their

Letter To The Editor
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Sir, I am taking this occasion to relate my pleasure
upon reading a recent article, entitled "Minsky and
Benny."
I, myself, have made an especial study of the subject
contained therein—to-wit, the burlesque; and, sir, let
me say that. your correspondent has by no means exaggerated. Burlesque today is one of the most respectable and justly remunerative professions there is. Cantor, Wynn, J. E. Brown, and many others have used
it as a spring-board to fame. And since the ,vaudeville
business has been dealt a serious blow by the talkies,
there can be no doubt of it. The illegitimate theatre
has come into its own! Even I, sir, have contemplated
giving up my pulpit work to sport about like a carefree child over the happy boards.
I have often visited the local burlesque palaces, sir,
and I assure you that the prolific abundance of rare
women was amazing to me no less than to your correspondent I, too, was interested.
With best of wishes,
HUGO D. WEISGALL,
Graduate Student In History.

bells and to find an experienced Russian player. Consequently, his dinner music will probably consist of

Blue Hens Swim Jay
Jay Natators The Truth
In Final Meet Will Out

Walks

By KEN ZIERLER

Dr. Shaffer said, "It's a good policy
to know the truth."

Hopkins Faces Delaware Fish
At K. Of C. Pool Tonight;
MacGill Expected To Star

Delaware Powerful
Additional Encounter May
Be Held With RandolphMacon College Tankers
In an attempt to score their third
win of the season, the Jay natators
will come to grips with the strong
Delaware aggregation in the K. of C.
pool tonight. The contest will mark
the end of dual meet competition for
the season, and Hopkins is anxious
to close up its campaign with a victory.
The job ahead of them is particularly difficult, however, because Delaware possesses one of the strongest
teams in the history of the college.
The opposing natators number among
their victims Carnegie Tech, a university that perennially turns out a
powerful squad and is one of the
strongest teams of the Eastern Intercollegiate League.
The Blue Jays will depend on the
same squad that took the trip to
Villanova and Manhattan last week to
garner points in the forthcoming engagement.
Coach
Hambleton's
charges experienced a rather successful week-end, trouncing Villanova
and tying the New Yorkers in
points, although losing the encounter
on a technical ruling.
Featuring the trip was the shattering of two records, the 150-yard
backstroke and the 200-yard breaststroke. Johnny MacGill accounted
for the former mark against Manhattan, covering the distance in 1:55
to cut 4-5 of a second off his own
record. Bill Hazlett lowered the
breaststroke time from Eddie Sadtler's performance of 2:50 to 2:47.
MacGill and Danny Weiner are
looked for to tally heavily in the
dorsal swim, while Hazlett and Bishop should bring the Jays some points
in the breaststroke. In the sprints
Lou Adler, who scored well against
Manhattan; Don Noonan and Charlie
Jones will compete against the dash
men from Delaware. Eddie Scheer and
Bud Adler will swim the 220 and 440,
the former having captured the
shorter race against Villanova. Bill
Koenig, winner against Manhattan,
and Capt. Bill McConnell will vie
with the opposition for the judge's
decision in the diving.
While the Delaware encounter is
the last meet on the regular schedule, there is a possibility of a contest
with Randolph-Macon if the Jays can
provide a satisfactory guarantee.
Some of the members of the team
also plan to travel to Pittsburgh for
the Eastern Collegiate championships, while it is planned to enter the
squad in the South Atlantics.
